video_path: C:\Users\chris\Dropbox\Scripts\clip-video\brands\KCD-UK\videos\Hannah Foxwell - Do Platform Engineers Need to Care About GenAI (Spoiler Alert, Yes!).mp4
text: Good morning everyone I'm here to talk a little bit about platforms and platform teams think this is a bit of a myth Platform engineers build stuff with kubernetes In fact I know that this is a myth because the first platform team I ever managed was back in 2011 14 years ago And our job was to protect the development teams that we were working with from all the complexity of the infrastructure the path to production the operations the config management We had some very early first generation automation tools that allowed us to do that way way before containers and kubernetes became the hot new thing That makes me sound old doesn't it I've been doing this platform thing for 14 years The only appropriate response to that is to come up to me in the break and say Hannah you don't look old enough That's the only appropriate response But yes platform engineering is not just about kubernetes Another common myth Platform engineering is all about developer productivity Let's get developers doing things faster I was product director at Snyk a cybersecurity company and I can tell you that the product we built was absolutely a platform but we weren't just trying to make developers more productive we were trying to make security teams more successful I think if you're a platform engineer in this room it's an often forgotten user of your platform the security teams that you're enabling as part of that So if platforms aren't all about cloud native and kubernetes and containers what are platforms all about For me I always sort of go back to basics here I say can you tell me why you're building a platform Within the context of your organization your team your business your customers can you tell me why your platform needs to exist And then the technology choices they follow on from that Here's a definition of a platform that I quite like This is from Team Topologies They've just released the second edition of Team Topologies and so this definition may have changed I haven't had time to read the new book yet but this is one that I quite like Team Topologies defines a platform as an internal product a set of services tools and APIs provided by a platform team that enables other teams to self‑serve accelerating their delivery and reducing cognitive load by abstracting away complexity By this definition I was building a platform back in 2011 So I'm going to go back to basics today Technology agnostic for a little while Why do we talk about platforms I think we talk about platforms because it's a really really useful mental model when we think about how we organize ourselves to deliver software to our Very very simple diagram Completely oversimplified This is not an architecture This is a way of thinking about it So you have application teams and they are serving your end users whoever they may be It may be e‑commerce it may be a bank it could be anything but you build amazing experiences and products that serve their users The platform serves them It serves the developers who are delivering the products and services to their users and your users are actually your internal development teams And of underneath it all you have some infrastructure which you could consider a platform in itself and the infrastructure teams are serving multiple users They might be serving the application teams directly or they might be serving the platform teams that build those higher level abstractions on top of it I'm going to pause at this moment in time to get a bit of a in terms of like how many platform teams or platform engineers we have in the room So wave your hands if you think you work on a platform team Waving waving waving Keep waving at me if your platform team has a product manager Oh a few hands went down Okay Keep waving at me if your product manager is doing regular user interviews and user research I've got two hands at the back Awesome Awesome Okay So this talk won't be sort of 101 level for some of you So if your platform engineering team does not have a product manager is not regularly doing user research then some of the things I'm going to talk about might be new news to you I hope they won't be But at every level of this very oversimplified diagram we have a product team and the product team has users and they are delivering an amazing product and a valuable service for their users Their users are different The platform team is delivering an amazing product and a valuable service for their users And those users are the application teams Now at the beginning of this I said I was going to talk about AI Sorry But we have some evolving user needs across our organizations as it is today We have application teams who are wanting to deliver Gen AI or LLM powered assistance We have AI agents We want to be chatbots whether those be internal or to our customers externally And we want to be automating using this new technology using agentic workflows Some of the platform capabilities that are needed to enable those new user experience include LLMs Whether you decide to plug into a SaaS via an API whether you want to self host a llama you need to be providing a large language model as a service to your organization These things are becoming ubiquitous These things are not optional anymore You need to integrate it with data and APIs You need to integrate it with the knowledge and the context of your organization in order for those things to become genuinely useful Do not ‑‑ this is just a sidebar but do not rely on the knowledge that is internalized in the LLM in order to get things done in your context You're not going to get very far These agents and these agency processes they must have the context and the guardrails of your organization to be successful And of course in the developer tool space AI coding agents anyone Give me a wave if you used a coding agent recently Yes That is one of the enormous transformations that we've ever seen in the software development landscape The ability to instruct in natural language an AI coding agent and have it write software for you I'm going to talk more about that in a minute But in the infrastructure layer we have new considerations new services that we might need to provide GPUs vector stores and we might need to do that with the existing databases and clusters that we have in our portfolio at the moment As I said I truly think that there are some evolving and emerging user needs in our organizations around Gen AI for developers and platform teams Gen AI is completely redefining our software development life cycle It's accelerating it massively in many cases So I've lived through and worked through the adoption of agile practices where we went from delivering releases once every three to six months to shipping something new every two weeks Or even better shipping every change into production using a continuous delivery pipeline hundreds and thousands of changes shipping every day That was an enormous step change Then we had containers Containers allowed us to remove the complexity of like it works on my machine it doesn't work production Why is that That was another acceleration And now we have coding agents that can spew out hundreds of lines of code in minutes And we need to make sure that those don't destabilize our products and our services that we're delivering to our users We need to make sure they don't degrade our security We need to think about how our internal platforms can enable us to seize this moment and to go faster but to go faster safely 90  of technology professionals now use AI in their work is one of the statistics from the DORA report And Nathan Harvey was speaking at a conference last week and he said if 90  of technology professionals who were surveyed say that they're using AI in their work that 10  are lying Because everyone is right Everyone is Whether you know it or not These capabilities are creeping into every single product and platform that we use as part of our path to And so I think about it this way I'm like okay who are my users My developers are they doing today that they weren't doing yesterday They're coding with AI powered tools and they're building new products with AI powered capabilities So you're building with AI and you're building with AI But the way I think about it is like actually even if you're not building a product that's sort of supercharged by like LLMs and AI you're probably still using these as capabilities within your software development lifecycle So it's touching everyone It's touching every single one of your users How as a platform team can you help them with this change I kind of covered this bit already haven't I So yeah like any product your platform must evolve and respond to the needs of your users And so you may have a roadmap that stretches out into the distance a three six month roadmap for your platform But what I would urge you to do today is to go and do some user research Find out what's the greatest worry for your development team today Find out what changes they're navigating and figure out how you can help them As I said we've got new emerging needs in all layers of the application stack that are being driven by gen AI And we can help to make this possible by taking a platform mindset We can reduce the cognitive load on our development team by providing paved roads Paved roads that provide the components and the capabilities that can be consumed as a service within your organization so that every development team that's sort of innovating with these technologies today they don't have to reinvent it every single time We can improve security by centralizing it and having a tiny bit of governance to make sure that we're doing the right things that we're doing sensible things with these AI agents Don't give them access to everything please And we can improve reliability by taking a more centralized approach We can take some of that burden away from the development teams and we can make sure that some of these things are ready for production earlier than they might have been otherwise There was an interesting survey recently that said something like 95  of AI pilots fail And my response to that was like yeah Like yeah Like pretty much Like this isn't this isn't this is not necessarily a failure This is an age of like incredible experimentation and innovation And we have these new things that we can build with And I don't think any of us are sure exactly what we should do with them And so we have to try and we have to experiment and we have to fail fast And so when people say oh my God 95  of pilots fail I don't view that as like an actual failure As long as you learn and as long as you take forward that learning and as long as we share that learning as a community One of the things that is tempting as a centralized platform team is to control and inhibit this innovation and this Especially if you're working in a highly regulated environment And so one thing I would urge you to is to pause and think about that Like what do we want to optimize for I would encourage you not to stifle that innovation You can organize and you can optimize for fast failure For learning and experimentation But you can only do those things if you choose that as your goal If you choose control and you choose gatekeeping and you say no my blessed Gen AI platform experience they're just not ready for you to use yet developers They'll find another way They'll find another solution You're not going to stop this You're just going to lose visibility So I would encourage you to go on this journey with your users Go on this journey with the innovation and experimentation And when you happen upon a success you can make that available to the rest of your organization as part of your platform So we go back to where we started Can you tell me why you're building a platform Is it about control Is it about security Is it about gatekeeping Or is it about driving innovation Is it about serving your developers reducing their cognitive load Is it about helping your organization change and evolve and There are so many repeatable patterns with AI that I'm seeing emerge across the businesses that I work with One of them is RAG retrieval augmented generation used by agents to access the knowledge and integrated using MCP the model context protocol I don't have time to explain all of these things to you but this is a pattern that I'm seeing emerging a repeatable pattern that a platform engineering team can make available to their users very quickly and very easily Just as one example so you might have a team working on a way to access the developer documentation internally through a natural language interface and they might be their own stack to see whether that's possible Another team might be looking at providing tools to the support organization How do we surface customer FAQs through natural language And another one might be looking at corporate policies and they might be looking at okay well how can we make it possible for employees to access this without having to raise a ticket with HR to get the answers that they need quicker And these are all the same architecture These are all the same architecture that can be reused and so as a platform team how powerful would it be if we can make these capabilities available as a service and allow development teams to experiment and work with their users to figure out what use cases are most powerful How do we avoid the sprawl of inventing the same thing over and over and over again in every development team for every use case These are just some of the things This is like my very quick brain dump of some of the capabilities that your platform might want to make available to your developers As I said RAG pipelines vector databases LLMs as a service whether that be on prem or whether that be one of the cloud providers AI security scanning tools so that you can scan your AI generated code as it's built so that you can black box test your LLM based applications to figure out whether or not they are vulnerable to jailbreaking for example An MCP tools catalog an agent builder how to guides communities I could go on and on and on These are all things that would genuinely help your development team today they navigate this change And so what I'm up here on the stage telling you this morning is that I think perhaps we need to build a platform for this and I think perhaps the people in this room are some of the best placed to do that Can we build an amazing product and a valuable service for our users the developers who are navigating so much change right now So I asked the question at the beginning do platform engineers need to care about Gen AI It's like saying does a product team need to care about their users Right It's a no brainer It's a yes And so as you leave here today one thing that I would urge you to do is to go and to talk to your developers and to build an amazing product and a valuable service for them And to have Gen AI and all of the capabilities that it is bringing to your organisations at the front of your mind while you try to figure out how best to help them do what they're doing right now My name's Hannah I am going to be around all week and I would love to chat to you more about some of the platforms that I'm seeing out in the world that are supporting Gen AI adoption
